page.title: 02History of Leighfield Forest
page.content: Leighfield was originally a deer park and the lodges lying within it were hunting lodges used by the gentry for hunting parties. The County boundary by Launde Park Wood follows a deep ditch and hedge which formed the deer boundary. Prior to the 1938_45 war the only remaining areas of forest were Priors Coppice (830055) and Launde Park Wood (803035) and the rest of the area was used for grazing. With the advent of the 1938-45 war, the Ministry of Agriculture took over the land, ploughed it, and used it for food production. The hedges were kept intact until after the war. The land was sold to the Merchant Venturers who rent it to a farming company. Many of the original hedges have now been removed to make larger fields.
